report_title: Industry Report on Greeting Card Publishing
executive_summary: The proliferation of paperless substitutes has dampened revenue for the industry. Many products, such as greeting cards, day planners and calendars, have increasingly been rendered obsolete as more consumers prefer digital alternatives, aided by the ubiquity of the smartphone. Overall, industry revenue is expected to decline at a CAGR of 4.3%, totaling an estimated $5.7 billion in 2024. Revenue is expected to fall 2.2% in 2024 alone, as industry profit slips to a meager 1.3%.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: The emergence of digital substitutes has threatened industry performance
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The industry has contended with growing competition from low-cost digital alternatives and no-cost social media interaction. Brick-and-mortar greeting card customers are acknowledging the shift in consumer preference toward digital substitutes.

External competition from digital substitutes has become the leading cause of industry contraction. Many traditional greeting card publishers have either diversified their offerings or shifted their businesses entirely online.

The pandemic significantly hastened the industry's decline by disrupting supply chains, decreasing adequate supply and preventing direct access to consumers through retail. Major players like Hallmark suspended activity at multiple facilities.
Many digital technologies have led consumers to consider traditional products as obsolete. The continued usage of electronic cards (e-cards) has amplified price-based competition in the industry.

Some industry enterprises have moved toward developing a market niche by offering greeting cards with technological additions like recording features and LED lights to create interactive greeting cards.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Smaller Companies Carve Out a Niche
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: A rise in demand for bespoke, handcrafted greeting cards has led to a surge in small-scale artisans and boutique businesses that offer unique, high-quality alternatives to mass-produced cards.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Industry Struggles Continue as Revenue and Profit Waver
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The industry will continue to struggle to generate revenue due to mounting external competition and the lingering effects of the pandemic on the broader retail sector.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Industry profitability will continue to contract
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Industry profitability will continue to contract as the rising cost of paper, a key input commodity for publishers, precipitates higher average purchase expenses.

The industry will continue grappling with increased competition from digital substitutes. Many publishing companies will expand their online brand presence and offer customizable greeting cards that integrate technology.

Poor industry performance has incited some enterprises to offer low-price greeting cards in dollar store chains. Consolidation in downstream markets will strengthen the ability to negotiate low prices for greeting cards, hampering industry revenue.
Publishers need to adapt by offering customizable cards and eco-friendly options made from recycled materials to meet consumer demands for personalization and sustainability.

industry_definition: This industry comprises publishers that primarily publish greeting cards in print or electronic form. Some companies also publish products such as postcards, calendars, coloring books, yearbooks and more. This industry excludes newspaper, magazine, book, directory, map, atlas, database and music publishers.
key_trends: Due to the industry's diverse product portfolio, greeting card and other publishers compete on several factors. Price-based competition is an integral basis of competition for industry enterprises.
Consolidation in downstream markets has tilted leverage for contract negotiation away from publishers, intensifying price-based competition as the customer market becomes increasingly concentrated.

Digital substitutes have been trending and have increasingly sapped away demand from greeting card publishers. This effect has been exacerbated by the disruption of brick-and-mortar stores by the pandemic, leading to revenue declines.

The looming threat of product obsolescence has forced industry enterprises to innovate. Smaller-scale competitors unable to sustain themselves have succumbed to consolidation as more prominent enterprises have seen an uptick in acquisition activity as high paper prices pressure the industry.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Younger generations are increasingly becoming accustomed to a fully digitized world. Applications such as Google Calendar, e-vites and websites such as Facebook and Instagram have shifted younger demographics away from products due to their ease and cost-effectiveness.

Although consumers in the 25- to 44-year-old demographic generally have full-time occupations and, therefore, may opt for the convenience and availability of a digital substitute over industry products, individuals within this group typically value physical messages more than younger demographics.

While the practice of writing "thank you" notes and event invitations has largely fallen out of style in younger generations, who favor e-vites and direct messaging, it is still common among individuals aged 45 to 64. Individuals of these age groups are among the last generations raised without the on-demand social interaction ushered in by the Information Age and, therefore, are more likely to retain values and customs that keep legacy industries alive.
According to the US Postal Service, older individuals typically send the largest volume of greeting cards each year, which has only increased in recent years.

Corporate culture has shifted as the eldest members of this demographic have entered leadership positions; demand from businesses is stagnating as companies have cut back on greeting card purchases amid the pandemic.

products_and_services.product_description: Greeting cards fall into two broad categories: seasonal and occasional. Occasion greeting cards make up the most considerable portion of greeting card sales. In particular, the most popular occasion card is for birthdays, followed by other secondary occasions that include: Sympathy, Thank You, Wedding, Thinking of You and Get Well, among other greeting cards.
Greeting cards sold in box sets.

The consumer publishing product segment includes products published for consumers, excluding newspapers, periodicals, and books. Yearbooks make up this segment's largest share, followed by calendars and other products. This segment also includes coloring books, pattern books, postcards and posters.
This product segment includes products published for businesses, trade and professionals; however, it excludes publications for newspapers, periodicals and books.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Print advertising expenditures represent advertisements in business publications, magazines, and national and local newspapers. Although encompassing products outside the industry's scope, print advertising expenditures are a proxy for general preference or lack thereof for physical media over digital. Declines in print advertising expenditures pose a potential threat to the industry.

A climb in consumer spending may lead to more consumers purchasing high-cost greeting cards, such as interactive greeting cards. Revitalized consumer discretionary spending incites businesses to purchase mail-order catalogs from industry publishers. Conversely, a decline in consumer spending often leads to reduced sales, as consumers may opt for personalized messages instead. Growth in consumer spending represents a potential opportunity for the industry.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Demand From Gift Shops and Card Stores
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Gift Shops and Card Stores sell greeting cards, art prints, posters, calendars, and postcards. As they experience larger sales volumes, they will require more products to stock their retail shelves. Greeting card publishers heavily rely on these outlets for their product sales. If demand from these shops drops, publishers face a dip in revenue, potentially harming industry performance.

Bookstores typically sell greeting cards and other publishing products. Bookstore consolidation has caused the complete liquidation of some stores, such as Borders Group Inc., resulting in an oversupply of stocked items. Fewer bookstores have required greeting cards and other products. If bookstores boost their orders, publishers thrive by ramping up production to meet this demand, boosting sales and revenue. However, a decline in bookstore demand can trigger a downturn in the publishers' performance, as it will result in a drop in sales, forcing publishers to reduce their output.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Number Of Children Aged Nine And Younger
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Children are significant recipients and purchasers of greeting cards, coloring books, posters, and art publications. Educational institutions and students represent a major market for yearbooks. This demographic is a crucial driver, triggering celebrations like birthdays and milestones and catalyzing greeting card sales. Growth in the number of children aged nine and younger bolsters industry revenue.

business_locations.location_description: The West accounts for a prominent portion of industry establishments, overrepresenting its share of the national population. California is not only the largest state contributor to industry activity within the region but also nationally.

The southeast region maintains the headquarters for major player American Greetings. The region is forecast to account for nearly a quarter of both the total domestic population and gift shops and card stores, underscoring the strategy for enterprises to locate in proximity to highly populous end markets. Florida represents the second-largest state contributor to industry activity, representing a greater proportion of industry establishments than its respective share of the population.

The Mid-Atlantic region captures a significant amount of industry activity that falls in line with its population density. Within the region, New York represents a key location for industry enterprises to leverage proximity to key downstream markets.

regulations_points.regulation_description: Companies must comply with intellectual property laws to protect product value and brands.
Publishers must adhere to postal service guidelines on size, weight and thickness of mailed items to remain cost-effective.
Laws ensure product safety, quality standards, and proper handling of customer data for personalized cards or databases.

barriers_points.barrier_description: The greeting card industry is in the decline stage of its life cycle.
The industry receives low and steady levels of assistance.
The industry faces high and increasing levels of competition.

factors_increased_barrier: The greeting card industry is in the decline stage of its life cycle.
factors_decreased_barrier: The industry has a low level of market concentration.

basis_points.basis_description: Price-based competition is an integral basis of competition for industry enterprises.
Many publishers compete for access to distribution networks, where larger publishers that can provide greeting cards in bulk to chain retailers will remain competitive.

concentration_points.concentration_description: Leading companies like Hallmark and American Greetings monopolize the industry and hold most of the market share.
Concentration varies between different product segments, with the greeting cards segment being highly concentrated.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: The price of paper, a key input commodity, has increased, putting pressure on publishers to determine appropriate pricing for paper-based products.
Many enterprises continue to outsource content production like artistic or editorial work to reduce wage expenses.
With acceleration in automation, companies are opting for technology over human labor to reduce costs, depressing overall wage costs.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Online card sales require technological infrastructure
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Publishers have invested in more technological infrastructure, such as computers and servers, to support online card sales platforms, but declining revenue has focused on capturing adequate labor.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Capital expenses vary by company operations
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Capital intensity varies considerably between companies and product segments based on whether they include manufacturing and distribution operations or outsource manufacturing to focus on product development.

volatility_points.volatility_description: A large portion of greeting cards experience seasonal volume cycles, with higher sales over holidays like Christmas, contributing to revenue volatility.
Consumer spending habits are unpredictable based on economic, social and individual factors, risking over/understock disruptions.
The continuous shift of consumers towards digital communication methods like emails and social media has caused fluctuations in greeting card revenues.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Companies use customized software to automate processes like card design layout and inserting barcodes, streamlining efficiency.
Touch-sensitive components allow publishers to manufacture interactive greeting cards with features like microphones, LEDs and recording.

FAQs.question: How have changes in consumers' electronic usage habits changed your operations?
FAQs.answer: Consumers have been increasing their use of electronic organizers, such as personal digital assistants and cell phones. This has adversely affected demand for paper-based organizers and calendars.

FAQs.question: How has the shift toward conducting business online affected demand for your services?
FAQs.answer: Electronic media and social networking websites will continue to affect demand for yearbooks, particularly from universities. Additionally, e-mail, social media websites and cell phone messaging has lowered demand for postcards.

FAQs.question: How has technological change affected the cost of serving your customers?
FAQs.answer: Online card sales have become significantly more important for industry companies in recent years. Publishers have had to invest in more technological infrastructure, like computers and servers, in order to host the e-commerce platforms that sell greeting cards online, raising purchasing costs.

FAQs.question: How have you reduced operational costs as the pandemic wore on?
FAQs.answer: Wage costs typically do not include outsourced or contracted content production, such as artistic or editorial work. In 2020, many companies began to focus more creative processes internally to reduce costs, while also investing in automation technology.

FAQs.question: How is your company leveraging new technology, particularly as it pertains to greeting card software?
FAQs.answer: Using customized software solutions for greeting cards automates the card design process and streamlines efficiency. For example, Hallmark automates its process of composing individual card design layouts by using software that inserts 8,000 card designs onto the card template before printing.

FAQs.question: Has your company been able to keep up with rapidly changing digital interfaces?
FAQs.answer: Innovations, such as using electrical circuits and small electronic widgets, have allowed industry operators to implement interactive design elements. This technology can be applied to manufacturing cards with touch-sensitive components, creating a market niche for interactive greeting cards.

FAQs.question: Has your company stayed ahead of regulations such as new environmental standards?
FAQs.answer: Industry companies are subject to federal regulations related to product safety, chemical use, air emissions, waste generation, the handling, management and disposal of waste, and remediation of contaminated sites. In 2021, the Biden Administration committed to more stringent environmental regulations during his first term, and companies that prepared for this shift in policy during the lows of 2020 will be best prepared to capitalize on changing demand trends.

FAQs.question: How does your company protect its intellectual property with copyrights, patents and trademarks?
FAQs.answer: Greeting card companies have a number of copyrights and trademarks to protect greeting card designs and verses. Industry publishers may also file for a patent, although their greeting card has to have a functional or mechanical aspect to be patent eligible.

FAQs.question: How have your company's profit margins compared to your main competitors' during the pandemic?
FAQs.answer: Average industry profit, as measured by earnings before taxes and interest, is estimated to have dropped significantly in 2020 as operators were not able to stimulate demand from customers, even when competing based on price and cutting into margins.

FAQs.question: What ongoing financing challenges does your company face, and can they be alleviated by more favorable interest rates spurred by the pandemic?
FAQs.answer: Operators are increasingly using higher quality images and printing papers for many of their products. Accordingly, use of printing plates, blocks, ink, paper, adhesives and photographic film has caused industry purchasing costs to become more expensive.

FAQs.question: Have you invested in automation? What effect has automation had on your output during the pandemic?
FAQs.answer: Automation benefits industries producing mass quantities of specific products. Companies that have been trying to reduce wage costs through automation long-term were more successful at navigating the pandemic, and therefore, more successful.

FAQs.question: Which niches, if any, do you cater to? How can you diversify your product mix? How do you keep track of the latest trends?
FAQs.answer: Publishers must be able to identify a niche market, and then effectively serve it. However, operators with broad, price-diverse product lines have been more successful, as they can better capture a wider market.

FAQs.question: Does your company have close relationships with several downstream buyers? How can you cultivate these relationships as demand dwindles in 2021?
Control of distribution arrangements
FAQs.answer: Strong distribution networks can be very important to some products and in some market segments. Operators that have a diverse roster of clients avoid declines as their risk is more spread out.

FAQs.question: How can you market your products so consumers find value in print over digital? Has the pandemic provided opportunities to combine technology with your products?
What proportion of your sales are to book stores? How was demand from this market affected by the closure of nonessential businesses?
FAQs.answer: Book stores typically sell greeting cards and other publishing products. Years of brick-and-mortar declines were compounded in 2020, as the pandemic spread and stay-at-home orders wiped out retail foot traffic for the majority of the year.

FAQs.question: Do you monitor changes in consumer spending? How did strongly negative trends in consumer spending in the wake of the pandemic influence your total revenue?
FAQs.answer: Rises in consumer spending lead to more consumers purchasing high-cost greeting cards, such as interactive greeting cards. Though steep declines in consumer confidence helped crater industry revenue, reopening of the economy helped companies somewhat.
